00022   /*
00023     # Return a Node collection of all possible paths through the given Node collection of Node collections.
00024     #
00025     # @param arrs [NodeCollection<NodeCollection<Node>>]
00026     # @return [NodeCollection<NodeCollection<Node>>]
00027     #
00028     # @example
00029     #   paths([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5]]) #=>
00030     #     # [[1, 3, 5],
00031     #     #  [2, 3, 5],
00032     #     #  [1, 4, 5],
00033     #     #  [2, 4, 5]]
00034   */
00035   Node paths(const Node& arrs, Context& ctx);

00038   /*
00039   This class is a default implementation of a Node comparator that can be passed to the lcs function below.
00040   It uses operator== for equality comparision. It then returns one if the Nodes are equal.
00041   */
00042   class DefaultLcsComparator {
00043   public:
00044     bool operator()(const Node& one, const Node& two, Node& out) const {
00045       // TODO: Is this the correct C++ interpretation?
00046       // block ||= proc {|a, b| a == b && a}
00047       if (one == two) {
00048         out = one;
00049         return true;
00050       }
00051 
00052       return false;
00053     }
00054   };
00055

00057   typedef vector<vector<int> > LCSTable;

00060   /*
00061   This is the equivalent of ruby's Sass::Util.lcs_backtrace.
00062 
00063   # Computes a single longest common subsequence for arrays x and y.
00064   # Algorithm from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_common_subsequence_problem#Reading_out_an_LCS
00065   */
00066   template<typename ComparatorType>
00067   Node lcs_backtrace(const LCSTable& c, const Node& x, const Node& y, int i, int j, const ComparatorType& comparator) {
00068     DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "LCSBACK: X=" << x << " Y=" << y << " I=" << i << " J=" << j)
00069 
00070     if (i == 0 || j == 0) {
00071       DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "RETURNING EMPTY")
00072       return Node::createCollection();
00073     }
00074 
00075     NodeDeque& xChildren = *(x.collection());
00076     NodeDeque& yChildren = *(y.collection());
00077 
00078     Node compareOut = Node::createNil();
00079     if (comparator(xChildren[i], yChildren[j], compareOut)) {
00080       DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "RETURNING AFTER ELEM COMPARE")
00081       Node result = lcs_backtrace(c, x, y, i - 1, j - 1, comparator);
00082       result.collection()->push_back(compareOut);
00083       return result;
00084     }
00085 
00086     if (c[i][j - 1] > c[i - 1][j]) {
00087       DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "RETURNING AFTER TABLE COMPARE")
00088       return lcs_backtrace(c, x, y, i, j - 1, comparator);
00089     }
00090 
00091     DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "FINAL RETURN")
00092     return lcs_backtrace(c, x, y, i - 1, j, comparator);
00093   }
00094 
00095 
00096   /*
00097   This is the equivalent of ruby's Sass::Util.lcs_table.
00098 
00099   # Calculates the memoization table for the Least Common Subsequence algorithm.
00100   # Algorithm from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_common_subsequence_problem#Computing_the_length_of_the_LCS
00101   */
00102   template<typename ComparatorType>
00103   void lcs_table(const Node& x, const Node& y, const ComparatorType& comparator, LCSTable& out) {
00104     DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "LCSTABLE: X=" << x << " Y=" << y)
00105 
00106     NodeDeque& xChildren = *(x.collection());
00107     NodeDeque& yChildren = *(y.collection());
00108 
00109     LCSTable c(xChildren.size(), vector<int>(yChildren.size()));
00110 
00111     // These shouldn't be necessary since the vector will be initialized to 0 already.
00112     // x.size.times {|i| c[i][0] = 0}
00113     // y.size.times {|j| c[0][j] = 0}
00114 
00115     for (size_t i = 1; i < xChildren.size(); i++) {
00116       for (size_t j = 1; j < yChildren.size(); j++) {
00117         Node compareOut = Node::createNil();
00118 
00119         if (comparator(xChildren[i], yChildren[j], compareOut)) {
00120           c[i][j] = c[i - 1][j - 1] + 1;
00121         } else {
00122           c[i][j] = max(c[i][j - 1], c[i - 1][j]);
00123         }
00124       }
00125     }
00126 
00127     out = c;
00128   }
00129

00131   /*
00132   This is the equivalent of ruby's Sass::Util.lcs.
00133 
00134   # Computes a single longest common subsequence for `x` and `y`.
00135   # If there are more than one longest common subsequences,
00136   # the one returned is that which starts first in `x`.
00137 
00138   # @param x [NodeCollection]
00139   # @param y [NodeCollection]
00140   # @comparator An equality check between elements of `x` and `y`.
00141   # @return [NodeCollection] The LCS
00142 
00143   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_common_subsequence_problem
00144   */
00145   template<typename ComparatorType>
00146   Node lcs(Node& x, Node& y, const ComparatorType& comparator, Context& ctx) {
00147     DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "LCS: X=" << x << " Y=" << y)
00148 
00149     Node newX = Node::createCollection();
00150     newX.collection()->push_back(Node::createNil());
00151     newX.plus(x);
00152 
00153     Node newY = Node::createCollection();
00154     newY.collection()->push_back(Node::createNil());
00155     newY.plus(y);
00156 
00157     LCSTable table;
00158     lcs_table(newX, newY, comparator, table);
00159 
00160     return lcs_backtrace(table, newX, newY, static_cast<int>(newX.collection()->size()) - 1, static_cast<int>(newY.collection()->size()) - 1, comparator);
00161   }

00164   /*
00165   This is the equivalent of ruby sass' Sass::Util.flatten and [].flatten.
00166   Sass::Util.flatten requires the number of levels to flatten, while
00167   [].flatten doesn't and will flatten the entire array. This function
00168   supports both.
00169 
00170   # Flattens the first `n` nested arrays. If n == -1, all arrays will be flattened
00171   #
00172   # @param arr [NodeCollection] The array to flatten
00173   # @param n [int] The number of levels to flatten
00174   # @return [NodeCollection] The flattened array
00175   */
00176   Node flatten(const Node& arr, Context& ctx, int n = -1);

00179   /*
00180   This is the equivalent of ruby's Sass::Util.group_by_to_a.
00181 
00182   # Performs the equivalent of `enum.group_by.to_a`, but with a guaranteed
00183   # order. Unlike [#hash_to_a], the resulting order isn't sorted key order;
00184   # instead, it's the same order as `#group_by` has under Ruby 1.9 (key
00185   # appearance order).
00186   #
00187   # @param enum [Enumerable]
00188   # @return [Array<[Object, Array]>] An array of pairs.
00189 
00190   TODO: update @param and @return once I know what those are.
00191 
00192   The following is the modified version of the ruby code that was more portable to C++. You
00193   should be able to drop it into ruby 3.2.19 and get the same results from ruby sass.
00194 
00195     def group_by_to_a(enum, &block)
00196       order = {}
00197 
00198       arr = []
00199 
00200       grouped = {}
00201 
00202       for e in enum do
00203         key = block[e]
00204         unless order.include?(key)
00205           order[key] = order.size
00206         end
00207 
00208         if not grouped.has_key?(key) then
00209           grouped[key] = [e]
00210         else
00211           grouped[key].push(e)
00212         end
00213       end
00214 
00215       grouped.each do |key, vals|
00216         arr[order[key]] = [key, vals]
00217       end
00218 
00219       arr
00220     end
00221 
00222   */
00223   template<typename EnumType, typename KeyType, typename KeyFunctorType>
00224   void group_by_to_a(vector<EnumType>& enumeration, KeyFunctorType& keyFunc, vector<pair<KeyType, vector<EnumType> > >& arr /*out*/) {
00225 
00226     map<unsigned int, KeyType> order;
00227 
00228     map<KeyType, vector<EnumType> > grouped;
00229 
00230     for (typename vector<EnumType>::iterator enumIter = enumeration.begin(), enumIterEnd = enumeration.end(); enumIter != enumIterEnd; enumIter++) {
00231       EnumType& e = *enumIter;
00232 
00233       KeyType key = keyFunc(e);
00234 
00235       if (grouped.find(key) == grouped.end()) {
00236         order.insert(make_pair(order.size(), key));
00237 
00238         vector<EnumType> newCollection;
00239         newCollection.push_back(e);
00240         grouped.insert(make_pair(key, newCollection));
00241       } else {
00242         vector<EnumType>& collection = grouped.at(key);
00243         collection.push_back(e);
00244       }
00245     }
00246 
00247     for (unsigned int index = 0; index < order.size(); index++) {
00248       KeyType& key = order.at(index);
00249       vector<EnumType>& values = grouped.at(key);
00250 
00251       pair<KeyType, vector<EnumType> > grouping = make_pair(key, values);
00252 
00253       arr.push_back(grouping);
00254     }
00255   }
00256 
00257 
00258 }
